subject: Cybersecurity
title: Password Hashing: Why Databases Don't Store Your Password
description: A quick, practical guide to Password Hashing: Why Databases Don't Store Your Password.

hook.text: If a website stores your actual password, one breach exposes every user. Good sites never store it.

buildup.text: Instead, they hash your password and store the hash. When you log in, they hash your input and compare.

discovery.text: Even if attackers steal the database, they get hashes â€” not passwords. Reversing hashes is computationally infeasible.

twist.text: Salting adds random data to each password before hashing. Two users with 'password123' get different hashes.

climax.text: Modern password hashing (bcrypt, Argon2) is intentionally slow, making brute force attacks impractical.

punchline.text: Good websites don't know your password. They never did.

quiz.question: Why is salt added to passwords before hashing?
options: So identical passwords produce different hashes
To speed up the hashing process
